Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.

Label: Group ID
Notes: Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Label: Sponsor-Defined Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined reference number. May be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number from the procedure or test page.

Label: Link ID
Notes: Identifier used to link related records across domains.This may be a one-to-one or a one-to-many relationship.

Label: Link Group ID
Notes: Identifier used to link related records across domains.This will usually be a many-to-one relationship.

Label: Reported Agent Name
Notes: Verbatim medication name that is either preprinted or collected on a CRF.

Label: Modified Reported Name
Notes: If AGTRT is modified to facilitate coding, then AGMODIFY will contain the modified text.

Label: Standardized Agent Name
Notes: Standardized or dictionary-derived text description of AGTRT or AGMODIFY. Equivalent to the generic medication name in WHO Drug. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document. If an intervention term does not have a decode value in the dictionary, then AGDECOD will be left blank.

Label: Category for Agent
Notes: Used to define a category of agent. Examples: "CHALLENGE AGENT", "PET TRACER".

Label: Subcategory for Agent
Notes: Further categorization of agent.

Label: AG Pre-Specified
Notes: Used to indicate whether ("Y"/null) information about the use of a specific agent was solicited on the CRF.

Label: AG Occurrence
Notes: When the use of specific agent is solicited, AGOCCUR is used to indicate whether ("Y"/"N") use of the agent occurred. Values are null for agents not specifically solicited.

Label: Completion Status
Notes: Used to indicate that a question about a prespecified agent was not answered. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".

Label: Reason Procedure Agent Not Collected
Notes: Describes the reason a response to a question about the occurrence of a procedure agent was not collected. Used in conjunction with AGSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Label: Agent Class
Notes: Drug class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class value. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, follow guidance in Section 4.2.8.3, Multiple Values for a Non-result Qualifier Variable, or omit AGCLAS.

Label: Agent Class Code
Notes: Class code corresponding to AGCLAS. Drug class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class code. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, follow guidance in Section 4.2.8.3, Multiple Values for a Non-result Qualifier Variable, or omit AGCLASCD.

Label: Dose per Administration
Notes: Amount of AGTRT taken.

Label: Dose Description
Notes: Dosing amounts or a range of dosing information collected in text form. Units may be stored in AGDOSU. Examples: "200-400", "15-20".

Label: Dose Units
Notes: Units for AGDOSE and AGDOSTXT. Examples: "ng", "mg", "mg/kg".

Label: Dose Form
Notes: Dose form for AGTRT. Examples: "TABLET", "AEROSOL".

Label: Dosing Frequency per Interval
Notes: Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of AGDOSE within a specific time period. Example: "ONCE".

Label: Route of Administration
Notes: Route of administration for AGTRT. Example: "ORAL".

Label: Visit Number
Notes: 1. Clinical encounter number. \n 2. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.

Label: Visit Name
Notes: 1. Protocol-defined description of clinical encounter. \n 2. May be used in addition to VISITNUM and/or VISITDY.

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit
Notes: Planned study day of the visit based upon RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the arm for the element in which the agent administration started.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the start date/time of the agent administration started.

Label: Start Date/Time of Agent
Notes: The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by AGTRT and the dosing variables began.

Label: End Date/Time of Agent
Notes: The date/time when administration of the treatment indicated by AGTRT and the dosing variables ended.

Label: Study Day of Start of Agent
Notes: Study day of start of agent relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Study Day of End of Agent
Notes: Study day of end of agent relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Duration of Agent
Notes: Collected duration for an agent episode. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.

Label: Start Relative to Reference Period
Notes: Describes the start of the agent relative to sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR", "ONGOING", or "CONTINUING" was collected, this information may be translated into AGSTRF. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: End Relative to Reference Period
Notes: Describes the end of the agent relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR", "ONGOING", or "CONTINUING" was collected, this information may be translated into AGENRF. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: Start Relative to Reference Time Point
Notes: Identifies the start of the agent as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable AGSTTPT. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: Start Reference Time Point
Notes: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by AGSTRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15", "VISIT 1".

Label: End Relative to Reference Time Point
Notes: Identifies the end of the agent as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable AGENTPT. Identifies the end of the agent as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable AGENTPT. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: End Reference Time Point
Notes: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by AGENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25", "VISIT 2".

Notes: When dosing of a treatment is recorded over multiple successive records, this variable is applicable only for the (chronologically) last record for the treatment.

Notes: Used to facilitate identification of relationships between records.

Label: Reported Name of Procedure
Notes: Name of procedure performed, either preprinted or collected on a CRF.

Label: Standardized Procedure Name
Notes: Standardized or dictionary-derived name of PRTRT. If the codelist "PROCEDUR" is not used, the sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms in the external codelist element in the Define-XML document. If an intervention term does not have a decode value, then PRDECOD will be null.

Label: Category
Notes: Used to define a category of procedure values.

Label: Subcategory
Notes: Used to define a further categorization of PRCAT values.

Label: Pre-specified
Notes: Used when a specific procedure is pre-specified on a CRF. Values should be "Y" or null.

Label: Occurrence
Notes: Used to record whether a prespecified procedure occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific procedure is solicited.

Label: Indication
Notes: Denotes the indication for the procedure (e.g., why the procedure was performed).

Label: Dose
Notes: Amount of PRTRT administered. Not populated when PRDOSTXT is populated.

Label: Dose Description
Notes: Dosing information collected in text form. Examples: "<1", "200-400". Not populated when PRDOSE is populated.

Label: Dose Units
Notes: Units for PRDOSE, PRDOSTOT, or PRDOSTXT.

Label: Dose Form
Notes: Dose form for PRTRT.

Label: Dosing Frequency per Interval
Notes: Usually expressed as the number of doses given per a specific interval.

Label: Intended Dose Regimen
Notes: Text description of the intended schedule or regimen for the procedure.

Label: Route of Administration
Notes: Route of administration for PRTRT.

Label: Location of Procedure
Notes: Anatomical location of a procedure.

Label: Laterality
Notes: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing laterality.

Label: Directionality
Notes: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing directionality.

Label: Portion or Totality
Notes: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing the distribution, which means arrangement of, apportioning of.

Label: Visit Number
Notes: Clinical encounter number. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.

Label: Visit Name
Notes: Protocol-defined description of a clinical encounter.

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit
Notes: Planned study day of VISIT. Should be an integer.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the arm.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the start date/time of the procedure.

Label: Start Date/Time of Procedure
Notes: Start date/time of the procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: End Date/Time of Procedure
Notes: End date/time of the procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Study Day of Start of Procedure
Notes: Study day of start of procedure expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Study Day of End of Procedure
Notes: Study day of end of procedure expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Duration of Procedure
Notes: Collected duration of a procedure represented in ISO 8601 character format. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.

Label: Planned Time Point Name
Notes: Text description of time when a procedure should be performed. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See PRTPTNUM and PRTPTREF.

Label: Planned Time Point Number
Notes: Numerical version of planned time point used in sorting.

Label: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref
Notes: Planned elapsed time in ISO 8601 format relative to a planned fixed reference (PRTPTREF). This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date/time variable, but an interval, represented as ISO duration.

Label: Time Point Reference
Notes: Description of the fixed reference point referred to by PRELTM, PRTPTNUM, and PRTPT.

Label: Date/Time of Reference Time Point
Notes: Date/time for a fixed reference time point defined by PRTRTREF in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Start Relative to Reference Time Point
Notes: Identifies the start of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable PRSTTPT. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: Start Reference Time Point
Notes: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by PRSTRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15", "VISIT 1".

Label: End Relative to Reference Time Point
Notes: Identifies the end of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable PRENTPT. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: End Reference Time Point
Notes: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by PRENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25", "VISIT 2".

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.

Label: Group ID
Notes: Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Label: Sponsor-Defined Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined reference number. May be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on a Tobacco & Alcohol Use CRF page.

Label: Reported Name of Substance
Notes: Substance name. Examples: "CIGARETTES", "COFFEE".

Label: Modified Substance Name
Notes: If SUTRT is modified, then the modified text is placed here.

Label: Standardized Substance Name
Notes: Standardized or dictionary-derived text description of SUTRT or SUMODIFY if the sponsor chooses to code the substance use. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document.

Label: Category for Substance Use
Notes: Used to define a category of related records. Examples: "TOBACCO", "ALCOHOL", or "CAFFEINE".

Label: Subcategory for Substance Use
Notes: A further categorization of substance use. Examples: "CIGARS", "CIGARETTES", "BEER", "WINE".

Label: SU Pre-Specified
Notes: Used to indicate whether ("Y"/null) information about the use of a specific substance was solicited on the CRF.

Label: SU Occurrence
Notes: When the use of specific substances is solicited, SUOCCUR is used to indicate whether ("Y"/"N") a particular prespecified substance was used. Values are null for substances not specifically solicited.

Label: Completion Status
Notes: When the use of prespecified substances is solicited, the completion status indicates that there was no response to the question about the prespecified substance. When there is no prespecified list on the CRF, then the completion status indicates that substance use was not assessed for the subject.

Label: Reason Substance Use Not Collected
Notes: Describes the reason substance use was not collected. Used in conjunction with SUSTAT when value of SUSTAT is "NOT DONE".

Label: Substance Use Class
Notes: Substance use class. May be obtained from coding. When coding to a single class, populate with class value. If using a dictionary and coding to multiple classes, then follow Section 4.2.8.3, Multiple Values for a Non-result Qualifier Variable, or omit SUCLAS.

Label: Substance Use Class Code
Notes: Code corresponding to SUCLAS. May be obtained from coding.

Label: Substance Use Consumption
Notes: Amount of SUTRT consumed. Not populated if SUDOSTXT is populated.

Label: Substance Use Consumption Text
Notes: Substance use consumption amounts or a range of consumption information collected in text form. Not populated if SUDOSE is populated.

Label: Consumption Units
Notes: Units for SUDOSE, SUDOSTOT, or SUDOSTXT. Examples: "oz", "CIGARETTE", "PACK", "g".

Label: Dose Form
Notes: Dose form for SUTRT. Examples: "INJECTABLE", "LIQUID", "POWDER".

Label: Use Frequency Per Interval
Notes: Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of SUDOSE within a specific time period. Example: "Q24H" (every day).

Label: Total Daily Consumption
Notes: Total daily use of SUTRT using the units in SUDOSU. Used when dosing is collected as total daily dose. If a sponsor needs to aggregate the data over a period other than daily, then the aggregated total could be recorded in a supplemental qualifier variable.

Label: Route of Administration
Notes: Route of administration for SUTRT. Examples: "ORAL", "INTRAVENOUS".

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the arm for the element in which the substance use started. Null for substances that started before study participation.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the start date/time of the substance use. Null for substances that started before study participation.

Label: Start Date/Time of Substance Use
Notes: Start date/time of the substance use represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: End Date/Time of Substance Use
Notes: End date/time of the substance use represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Study Day of Start of Substance Use
Notes: Study day of start of substance use relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Study Day of End of Substance Use
Notes: Study day of end of substance use relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Duration of Substance Use
Notes: Collected duration of substance use in ISO 8601 format. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times.

Label: Start Relative to Reference Period
Notes: Describes the start of the substance use relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR" was collected, this information may be translated into SUSTRF. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: End Relative to Reference Period
Notes: Describes the end of the substance use with relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point (represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics). If information such as "PRIOR", "ONGOING", or "CONTINUING" was collected, this information may be translated into SUENRF. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: Start Relative to Reference Time Point
Notes: Identifies the start of the substance as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable SUSTTPT. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7 , Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: Start Reference Time Point
Notes: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by SUSTRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15", "VISIT 1".

Label: End Relative to Reference Time Point
Notes: Identifies the end of the substance as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable SUENTPT. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7 , Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: End Reference Time Point
Notes: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by SUENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25", "VISIT 2".

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sponsor Device Identifier
Notes: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify a specific device. Used to represent a device associated in some way with the adverse event. SPDEVID values are defined in the Device Identifiers (DI) domain.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.

Label: Group ID
Notes: Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Label: Reference ID
Notes: Internal or external identifier such as a serial number on an SAE reporting form.

Label: Sponsor-Defined Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined identifier. It may be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on an Adverse Events CRF page.

Label: Reported Term for the Adverse Event
Notes: Verbatim name of the event.

Label: Modified Reported Term
Notes: If AETERM is modified to facilitate coding, then AEMODIFY will contain the modified text.

Label: Lowest Level Term
Notes: Dictionary-derived text description of the lowest level term.

Label: Lowest Level Term Code
Notes: Dictionary-derived code for the lowest level term.

Label: Dictionary-Derived Term
Notes: Dictionary-derived text description of AETERM or AEMODIFY. Equivalent to the Preferred Term (PT in MedDRA). The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the external codelist element in the Define-XML document.

Label: Preferred Term Code
Notes: Dictionary-derived code for the preferred term.

Label: High Level Term
Notes: Dictionary-derived text description of the high level term for the primary system organ class (SOC).

Label: High Level Term Code
Notes: Dictionary-derived code for the high level term for the primary SOC.

Label: High Level Group Term
Notes: Dictionary-derived text description of the high level group term for the primary SOC.

Label: High Level Group Term Code
Notes: Dictionary-derived code for the high level group term for the primary SOC.

Label: Category for Adverse Event
Notes: Used to define a category of related records. Examples: "BLEEDING", "NEUROPSYCHIATRIC".

Label: Subcategory for Adverse Event
Notes: A further categorization of adverse event. Example: "NEUROLOGIC".

Label: Pre-Specified Adverse Event
Notes: A value of "Y" indicates that this adverse event was prespecified on the CRF. Values are null for spontaneously reported events (i.e., those collected as free-text verbatim terms).

Label: Body System or Organ Class
Notes: Dictionary derived. Body system or organ class used by the sponsor from the coding dictionary (e.g., MedDRA). When using a multi-axial dictionary such as MedDRA, this should contain the SOC used for the sponsor's analyses and summary tables, which may not necessarily be the primary SOC.

Label: Body System or Organ Class Code
Notes: Dictionary derived. Code for the body system or organ class used by the sponsor. When using a multi-axial dictionary such as MedDRA, this should contain the SOC used for the sponsor's analyses and summary tables, which may not necessarily be the primary SOC.

Label: Primary System Organ Class
Notes: Dictionary-derived text description of the primary SOC. Will be the same as AEBODSYS if the primary SOC was used for analysis.

Label: Primary System Organ Class Code
Notes: Dictionary-derived code for the primary SOC. Will be the same as AEBDSYCD if the primary SOC was used for analysis.

Label: Location of Event
Notes: Describes anatomical location relevant for the event (e.g., "ARM" for skin rash).

Label: Severity/Intensity
Notes: The severity or intensity of the event. Examples: "MILD", "MODERATE", "SEVERE".

Label: Serious Event
Notes: Is this a serious event? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Action Taken with Study Treatment
Notes: Describes changes to the study treatment as a result of the event. AEACN is specifically for the relationship to study treatment. AEACNOTH is for actions unrelated to dose adjustments of study treatment. Examples of AEACN values include ICH E2B values: "DRUG WITHDRAWN", "DOSE REDUCED", "DOSE INCREASED", "DOSE NOT CHANGED", "UNKNOWN" and "NOT APPLICABLE".

Label: Other Action Taken
Notes: Describes other actions taken as a result of the event that are unrelated to dose adjustments of study treatment. Usually reported as free text. Example: "TREATMENT UNBLINDED. PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN NOTIFIED".

Label: Action Taken with Device
Notes: An action taken with a device as the result of the event. The device may or may not be a device under study.

Label: Causality
Notes: Records the investigator's opinion as to the causality of the event to the treatment. ICH does not establish any required or recommended terms for non-device relatedness. ICH E2A and E2B examples include (up-cased here for alignment to SDTM conventions) terms such as "NOT RELATED", "UNLIKELY RELATED", "POSSIBLY RELATED", "RELATED", but these example terms do not establish any conventions or expectations. Controlled terminology may be defined in the future. Check with regulatory authority for population of this variable.

Label: Relationship of Event to Device
Notes:
A judgment as to the likelihood that the device caused the adverse event. The relationship is to a device identified in the data (i.e., has an SPDEVID). The device may be ancillary or under study. 
 Terminology: 
 * In the EU, follow the European Commission Guidelines on Medical Devices, Clinical Investigations: SAE Reporting (MEDDEV 2.7/3) (e.g., Not Related, Unlikely, Possible, Probable, Causal Relationship), with device-specific definitions. 
 * No required Controlled Terminology in US.

Label: Relationship to Non-Study Treatment
Notes: Records the investigator's opinion as to whether the event may have been due to a treatment other than study drug. May be reported as free text. Example: "MORE LIKELY RELATED TO ASPIRIN USE".

Label: Pattern of Adverse Event
Notes: Used to indicate the pattern of the event over time. Examples: "INTERMITTENT", "CONTINUOUS", "SINGLE EVENT".

Label: Outcome of Adverse Event
Notes: Description of the outcome of an event.

Label: Involves Cancer
Notes: Was the serious event associated with the development of cancer? Valid values are "Y" and "N". This is a legacy seriousness criterion. It is not included in ICH E2A or E2B.

Label: Congenital Anomaly or Birth Defect
Notes: Was the serious event associated with congenital anomaly or birth defect? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Persist or Signif Disability/Incapacity
Notes: Did the serious event result in persistent or significant disability/incapacity? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Results in Death
Notes: Did the serious event result in death? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Requires or Prolongs Hospitalization
Notes: Did the serious event require or prolong hospitalization? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Is Life Threatening
Notes: Was the serious event life-threatening? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Occurred with Overdose
Notes: Did the serious event occur with an overdose? Valid values are "Y" and "N". This is a legacy seriousness criterion. It is not included in ICH E2A or E2B.

Label: Other Medically Important Serious Event
Notes: Do additional categories for seriousness apply? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Needs Intervention to Prevent Impairment
Notes: Records whether medical or surgical intervention was necessary to preclude permanent impairment of a body function, or to prevent permanent damage to a body structure, with either situation suspected to be due to the use of a medical product. This variable is used in conjunction with the other "seriousness" variables (e.g., fatal, life-threatening). It is part of the US federal government definition of a serious adverse event; see 21 CFR Part 803.3(w)(3).

Label: Unanticipated Adverse Device Effect
Notes:
Any serious adverse effect on health or safety or any life-threatening problem or death caused by or associated with a device, if that effect, problem, or death was not previously identified in nature, severity, or degree of incidence in the investigational plan or application (including a supplementary plan or application), 
 or 
 any other unanticipated serious problem associated with a device that relates to the rights, safety, or welfare of subjects. (21 CFR Part 812.3(s)). 
 This variable applies only to serious AEs and should hold collected data; if the value is derived, it should be held in ADaM.

Label: Rel of AE to Non-Dev-Rel Study Activity
Notes:
The investigator's opinion as to the causality of the event as related to other protocol-required activities, actions, or assessments (e.g., medication changes, tests/assessments, other procedures). The relationship is to a protocol-specified, non-device-related activity where the device is identified in the data (i.e., has an SPDEVID). The device may be ancillary or under study. 
 Terminology: 
 * In the EU, follow the European Commission Guidelines on Medical Devices, Clinical Investigations: SAE Reporting (MEDDEV 2.7/3) (e.g., Not Related, Unlikely, Possible, Probable, Causal Relationship), with device-specific definitions. 
 * No required Controlled Terminology in US.

Label: Rel of AE to Device-Related Procedure
Notes:
The investigator's opinion as to the likelihood that the device-related study procedure (e.g., implant/insertion, revision/adjustment, explant/removal) caused the AE. The relationship is to a device-related procedure where the device is identified in the data (i.e., has an SPDEVID). The device may be ancillary or under study. 
 Terminology: 
 * In the EU, follow the European Commission Guidelines on Medical Devices, Clinical Investigations: SAE Reporting (MEDDEV 2.7/3) (e.g., Not Related, Unlikely, Possible, Probable, Causal Relationship), with device-specific definitions. 
 * No required Controlled Terminology in US.

Label: Concomitant or Additional Trtmnt Given
Notes: Was another treatment given because of the occurrence of the event? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Label: Standard Toxicity Grade
Notes: Toxicity grade according to a standard toxicity scale (e.g., Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events, CTCAE). Sponsors should specify the name of the scale and version used in the metadata (see assumption 7d). If value is from a numeric scale, represent only the number (e.g., "2", not "Grade 2").

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the arm.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the start date/time of the adverse event. Examples: "SCREENING", "TREATMENT", "FOLLOW-UP".

Label: Start Date/Time of Adverse Event
Notes: Start date/time of the adverse event represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: End Date/Time of Adverse Event
Notes: End date/time of the adverse event represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Study Day of Start of Adverse Event
Notes: Study day of start of adverse event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Study Day of End of Adverse Event
Notes: Study day of end of event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Duration of Adverse Event
Notes: Collected duration and unit of an adverse event. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from start and end date/times. Example: "P1DT2H" (for 1 day, 2 hours).

Label: End Relative to Reference Period
Notes: Describes the end of the event relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point (RFSTDTC) and a discrete ending point (RFENDTC) of the trial. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: End Relative to Reference Time Point
Notes: Identifies the end of the event as being before or after the reference time point defined by variable AEENTPT. \n Not all values of the codelist are allowable for this variable. See Section 4.4.7, Use of Relative Timing Variables.

Label: End Reference Time Point
Notes: Description of date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the reference point referred to by AEENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25", "VISIT 2".

Label: Reported Term for the Biospecimen Event
Notes: Topic variable for an event observation, which is the verbatim or pre-specified name of the event.

Label: Modified Reported Term
Notes: If the value for BETERM is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.

Label: Dictionary-Derived Term
Notes: Dictionary-derived text description of BETERM or BEMODIFY, if applicable.

Label: Category for Biospecimen Event
Notes: Used to define a category of topic-variable values. Example: COLLECTION, PREPARATION, TRANSPORT.

Label: Subcategory for Biospecimen Event
Notes: A further categorization of BECAT values.

Label: Anatomical Location of Event
Notes: Describes the anatomical location relevant for the event (e.g. BRAIN, LUNG).

Label: Visit Number

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit

Label: Date/Time of Specimen Collection
Notes: Date and time of specimen collection.

Notes: Start date/time of the event.

Label: End Date/Time of Biospecimen Event
Notes: End date/time of the event.

Label: Study Day of Start of Biospecimen Event
Notes: Actual study day of start of observation expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Study Day of End of Biospecimen Event
Notes: Actual study day of end of observation expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Duration of Biospecimen Event

Label: Subcategory for the Clinical Event
Notes: A further categorization of the condition or event.

Label: Clinical Event Occurrence

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm

Label: Date/Time of Event Collection

Label: Start Date/Time of Clinical Event
Notes: Start date/time of the clinical event represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: End Date/Time of Clinical Event
Notes: End date/time of the clinical event, represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Study Day of Event Collection
Notes: Study day of clinical event collection, measured as integer days. Algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in Demographics. This formula should be consistent across the submission.

Label: Study Day of Start of Event
Notes: Actual study day of start of the clinical event expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Study Day of End of Event
Notes: Actual study day of end of the clinical event expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Start Relative to Reference Period
Notes: Describes the start of the clinical event relative to the sponsor-defined reference period. Notes: Short name of the measurement, test, or examination described in CPTEST. It can be used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical to a horizontal format. The value in CPTESTCD cannot be longer than 8 characters, nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST" is not valid). CPTESTCD cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. Examples: "MONO", "MNS".

Label: Name of Measurement, Test or Examination
Notes: Long name for CPTESTCD. For cell phenotyping, the name (often abbreviated) of the cell population, as it is generally accepted by the scientific community, is populated (rather than a colloquial designation based on a primary marker, e.g., TLym Help rather than CD4). When the test is for a sublineage which can only be identified by specifying additional markers (i.e., has not been given a name) or which is further restricted to a subpopulation based on a particular cell state (e.g., activated, proliferating, apoptotic), the Sublineage Marker String (CPSBMRKS), Cell State (CPCELSTA), and Cell State Marker String (CPCSMRKS) variables are additionally populated and the value in CPTEST is suffixed with "Sub" to denote that it is a subset of the population identified in CPTEST (e.g., Monocytes Sub). \n The value in CPTEST cannot be longer than 40 characters.

Label: Sublineage Marker String
Notes: Used to further subset the cell population identified in CPTEST based on the use of additional marker(s) that define a sublineage. The value in CPSBMRKS is used in combination with values in CPTEST and CPCELSTA to fully describe the cell population being measured. As such, it is an essential component of the full test name. \n For example, three unnamed sublineages of monocytes have been identified as: CCR2+CD16-, CCR2-CD16+, and CCR2+CD16+. Whereas the entire monocyte cell population can be defined as CD14+ cells, the additional CCR2 and CD16 markers are used to differentiate one sublineage from another. As none of these sublineages have been given names, they are only known by the CCR2 and CD16 marker combinations. By associating the CPTEST value of "Monocytes Sub" with, for example, a value of "CCR2+CD16-" in CPSBMRKS, the full test is defined to be the CCR2+CD16- monocyte subpopulation.

Label: Cell State
Notes: A textual description of a subset of the cell population identified in CPTEST based on a particular functional and/or biological state (e.g., "ACTIVATED", "PROLIFERATING", "SENESCENT"). When populated, the values in CPCELSTA and CPSMRKS, in combination with the values in CPTEST and CPSBMRKS, fully describe the cell population being measured.

Label: Cell State Marker String
Notes: Identifies the marker(s) or indicator(s) used to define the cell state (i.e., the value in CPCELSTA). \n For example, when Ki67 expression is used to determine that a cell population is in a proliferating state (i.e., CPCELSTA value="PROLIFERATING"), the value "Ki67+" in CPCSMRKS indicates that positive expression of Ki67 was used to define the population as proliferating. Similarly, a value of "Ki67-" in CPCSMRKS would indicate that lack of expression of Ki67 defined the "NON-PROLIFERATING" cell state in CPCELSTA. The CPCSMRKS value is useful for quickly determining which marker(s) were used to classify (i.e., operationally define) a cell population based on a functional/biological state.

Label: Test Condition
Notes: Identifies any planned condition imposed by the assay system on the specimen at the time the test is performed. --TSTCND is generally used to distinguish between two or more records where the same assay is performed under varying (as opposed to fixed) conditions, usually for the purpose of making a comparison. For example, when the same assay (identified in --TEST) is performed under stimulated and non-stimulated conditions, the --TSTCND variable is used distinguish between the records.

Label: Test Condition Agent
Notes: The textual description of the agent, if applicable, used to impose the condition identified in CPTSTCND. For example, records might be produced for the same assay run under stimulating (CPTSTCND value = "STIMULATED") conditions produced by different stimulating agents (e.g., phorbol myristate acetate, concanavalin A, PHA-P, TNF-alpha, Ionomycin, candida antigen).

Label: Binding Agent
Notes: The textual description of the agent that is binding to the entity in the CPTEST variable. The CPBDAGNT variable is used to indicate that there is a binding relationship between the entities in the CPTEST and CPBDAGNT variables, regardless of direction. \n The binding agent may be, but is not limited to, a test article; a portion of a test article; a substance related to a test article; an endogenous molecule; an allergen; an infectious agent; or a reagent (e.g., primary antibody) that confers the binding specificity for the measurement defined in CPTEST when it is needed to uniquely identify the test.

Label: Antibody Clone Identifier
Notes: Identifies the antibody clone (e.g., supplier-provided catalog name) used to confer specificity for the binding agent specified in CPBDAGNT.

Label: Marker String
Notes: The text string identifying the full set of markers/indicators used by the laboratory to operationally define the complete test based on the combination of CPTEST, CPSBMRKS, and CPCELSTA. Because laboratories often use different markers/indicators to identify a cell population, the relationship between a named cell population in CPTEST (as combined with CPSBMRKS and CPCELSTA values) and the set of markers used to identify that population is many-to-one. To ensure nuances important for accurately interpreting the data are accounted for and which arise from the use of different sets of markers, it is necessary to operationally define the test in terms of the complete set of markers/indicators used to perform that test.

Label: Gate
Notes: The sponsor-defined name assigned to a gate. Gates are electronic (i.e., a device setting or software-defined) boundaries set by a user to virtually parse a specimen into discrete populations based on a set of defined characteristics (e.g., presence, absence, or intensity of expression of various markers; physical size; internal complexity or granularity). Gates are used to constrain data collection or analysis to a specific cell population or region of interest within the specimen.

Label: Gate Definition
Notes: The text string identifying the set of parameters and the order in which they are applied to define the gating strategy. In practice, a series of 2-dimensional sub-gates based on different cell characteristics (i.e., markers/indicators/physical properties) are most often combined until the cell population of interest is sufficiently resolved (i.e., electronically isolated) from other cell populations contained within the specimen. \n For complex analyses, differences in gating strategies can produce subtle differences in results obtained for a test. To ensure nuances important for accurately interpreting the data are accounted for and which arise from the use of different gating strategies, it is often necessary to qualify the test in terms of the gating strategy. For some purposes, however, and at the discretion of the sponsor, only the ultimate or penultimate gate is identified. When specifying the gating strategy in CPGATDEF, each sub-gate should be listed in the order it was applied and separated from the next sub-gate using the pipe/vertical line ("|") character.

Label: Sponsor Test Description
Notes: Sponsor's description of a test. The variable is intended to contain highly structured test description metadata used by a sponsor to unambiguously define (label) a test. Such values generally reside in a sponsor/laboratory test metadata repository. CPSPTSTD is not intended for unstructured (spontaneous) free text. \n An example of appropriate usage is when it is necessary to include identifying information for a target cell population on which a test is conducted when the target population is not part of the test name, e.g., tests for quantitative expression of a particular marker on a specific cell population.

Notes: Used to define a category of topic-variable values across subjects. Examples: "IMMUNOPHENOTYPING", "CELL FUNCTION", "TARGET ENGAGEMENT".

Notes: A further categorization of CPCAT.

Notes: Original units in which the data were collected. The unit for CPORRES. Examples: "10^6/L", "%", "MESF".

Label: Link Group ID

Label: Measurement, Test, or Examination Detail
Notes: Description of a reportable qualifying the assessment in GFTESTCD and GFTEST.

Label: Category for Genomic Finding
Notes: Used to define a category of topic-variable values.

Label: Subcategory for Genomic Finding
Notes: Used to define a further categorization of GFCAT values.

Label: Result or Finding in Original Units
Notes: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.

Label: Reference Result in Original Units

Label: Result or Finding in Standard Format

Label: Numeric Result/Finding in Standard Units
Notes: Used for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format; copied in numeric format from GFSTRESC. GFSTRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.

Label: Numeric Reference Result in Std Units

Label: Result Category
Notes: Used to categorize the result of a finding.

Label: Inheritability

Label: Genome Reference
Notes: An identifier for the genome reference used to generate the reported result. For example, Genome Reference Consortium Human Build 38 patch release 13 may be represented as "GRCh38.p13".

Label: Chromosome Identifier
Notes: The designation (name or number) of the chromosome or contig on which the variant or other feature appears (e.g., "17"; "X").

Label: Genomic Symbol

Label: Genomic Symbol Type
Notes: A description of the type of genomic entity that is represented by the published symbol in GFSYM.

Notes: Specifies the location within a sequence for the observed value in GFORRES.

Label: Genetic Sub-Region
Notes: The portion of the locus in which the variation was found. Examples: "Exon 15", "Kinase domain".

Label: Copy Identifier
Notes: An arbitrary identifier used to differentiate between copies of a genetic target of interest present on homologous chromosomes.

Label: Completion Status
Notes: Used to indicate that a question was not asked or a test was not done, or a test was attempted but did not generate a result. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".

Label: Reason Test Not Done

Label: External File Path

Label: Laboratory/Vendor Name

Label: Specimen Material Type

Label: Method of Test or Examination

Label: Run ID

Label: Analysis Method

Label: Baseline Flag

Label: Derived Flag

Label: Lower Limit of Quantitation

Label: Time Point Reference
Notes: Name of the fixed reference point referred to by GFELTM, GFTPTNUM, and GFTPT. Examples: "PREVIOUS DOSE", "PREVIOUS MEAL".

Label: Date/Time of Reference Time Point
Notes: Date/time for a fixed reference time point defined by GFTPTREF.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.

Label: Sponsor-Defined Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined reference number. May be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Inclusion or exclusion criteria number from CRF.

Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Criterion Short Name
Notes: Short name of the criterion described in IETEST. The value in IETESTCD cannot be longer than 8 characters, nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST" is not valid). IETESTCD cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. Examples: "IN01", "EX01".

Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Criterion
Notes: Verbatim description of the inclusion or exclusion criterion that was the exception for the subject within the study. IETEST cannot be longer than 200 characters.

Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Category
Notes: Used to define a category of related records across subjects.

Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Subcategory
Notes: A further categorization of the exception criterion. Can be used to distinguish criteria for a sub-study or for to categorize as a major or minor exceptions. Examples: "MAJOR", "MINOR".

Label: I/E Criterion Original Result
Notes: Original response to inclusion/exclusion criterion question, i.e., whether the inclusion or exclusion criterion was met.

Label: I/E Criterion Result in Std Format
Notes: Response to inclusion/exclusion criterion result, in standard format.

Label: Visit Number
Notes: Clinical encounter number. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.

Label: Visit Name
Notes: Protocol-defined description of clinical encounter. May be used in addition to VISITNUM and/or VISITDY.

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit
Notes: Planned study day of the visit based upon RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the arm for the element in which the assessment was made.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the observation date/time of the inclusion/exclusion finding.

Label: Date/Time of Collection
Notes: Collection date and time of the inclusion/exclusion criterion represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Group ID
Notes: Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Notes: Sponsor-defined identifier.

Label: Test Condition

Notes: Further description of ISTESTCD and ISTEST.

Notes: A further categorization of ISCAT.

Notes: Lower end of reference range for continuous measurements for ISSTRESC/ISSTRESN in standardized units. Should be populated only for continuous results.

Notes: Upper end of reference range for continuous measurements in standardized units. Should be populated only for continuous results.

Notes: For normal range values that are character in ordinal scale or if categorical ranges were supplied. Examples: "-1 to +1", "NEGATIVE TO TRACE".

Notes: Used to indicate a test was not done. Should be null if a result exists in ISORRES.

Notes: Describes why a measurement or test was not performed. Used in conjunction with ISSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Notes: Defines the types of specimen used for a measurement. Example: "SERUM".

Notes: Used to indicate a derived record. The value should be "Y" or null. Label: Lower Limit of Quantitation
Notes: Indicates the lower limit of quantitation for an assay. Units will be those used for ISSTRESU.

Label: Visit Number
Notes: Clinical encounter number. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.

Label: Visit Name
Notes: Protocol-defined description of a clinical encounter. May be used in addition to VISITNUM and/or VISITDY.

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit
Notes: Planned study day of the visit based upon RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the arm.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the start date/time of the observation, or the date/time of collection if start date/time is not collected.

Notes: End date/time of the observation.

Label: Study Day of End of Specimen Collection
Notes: Actual study day of end of observation expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Planned Time Point Name
Notes: Text description of time when specimen should be taken. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See ISTPTNUM and ISTPTREF. Examples: "Start", "5 min post".

Label: Planned Time Point Number
Notes: Numerical version of ISTPT to aid in sorting.

Examples: "-PT15M" to represent the period of 15 minutes prior to the reference point indicated by ISTPTREF, "PT8H" to represent the period of 8 hours after the reference point indicated by ISTPTREF.

Label: Time Point Reference
Notes: Name of the fixed reference point referred to by ISELTM, ISTPTNUM, and ISTPT. Examples: "PREVIOUS DOSE", "PREVIOUS MEAL".

Label: Date/Time of Reference Time Point
Notes: Date/time of the reference time point, ISTPTREF.

Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Label: Specimen ID

Notes: Sponsor-defined reference number. May be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database. Example: Line number on the Lab page.

Label: Lab Test or Examination Short Name
Notes: Short name of the measurement, test, or examination described in LBTEST. It can be used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical to a horizontal format. Examples: "ALT", "LDH".

Notes: Upper end of reference range for continuous measurement in original units. Should be populated only for continuous results.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Focus of Study-Specific Interest
Notes: Identification of a focus of study-specific interest on or within a subject or specimen as called out in the protocol for which a measurement, test, or examination was performed. The value in this variable should have inherent semantic meaning.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number to ensure uniqueness of records within a dataset for a subject. May be any valid number.

Label: Group ID
Notes: Optional group identifier, used to link together a block of related records within a subject in a domain.

Label: Reference ID
Notes: Internal or external specimen identifier (e.g., sample ID for a subject sample from which a microbial culture was generated).

Label: Sponsor-Defined Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined reference number. May be preprinted on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor's operational database.

Label: Link ID
Notes: Identifier used to link related records across domains. This may be a one-to-one or a one-to-many relationship. For example, it may be used to link genetic findings (in the PF domain) about a microbe to the original culture of that microbe (in MB), or to susceptibility records (in MS) if needed.

Label: Link Group ID
Notes: Identifier used to link related records across domains. This will usually be a many-to-one relationship.

Label: Microbiology Test or Finding Short Name
Notes: Short name of the measurement, test, or finding described in MBTEST. It can be used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical to a horizontal format. The value in MBTESTCD cannot be longer than 8 characters, nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST" is not valid). MBTESTCD cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. Examples: "MCORGIDN" for Microbial Organism Identification "GMNCOC" for Gram Negative Cocci.

Label: Microbiology Test or Finding Name
Notes: Verbatim name of the test or examination used to obtain the measurement or finding. The value in MBTEST cannot be longer than 40 characters. Examples: "Microbial Organism Identification", "Gram Negative Cocci", "HIV-1 RNA".

Label: Measurement, Test or Examination Detail
Notes: Further description of MBTESTCD and MBTEST. Example: "VIRAL LOAD" when MBTESTCD represents viral genetic material, such as "HCRNA", "QUANTIFICATION" when MBTESTCD represents any organism being quantified.

Label: Category
Notes: Used to define a category of related records.

Label: Subcategory
Notes: Used to define a further categorization of MBCAT values.

Label: Result or Finding in Original Units
Notes: Result of the microbiology measurement or finding as originally received or collected. Examples for "GRAM STAIN" findings: "+3 MODERATE", "+2 FEW", "<10". Examples for "CULTURE PLATE" findings: "KLEBSIELLA PNEUMONIAE", "STREPTOCOCCUS PNEUMONIAE".

Label: Original Units
Notes: Original unit for MBORRES. Example: "mcg/mL".

Label: Result or Finding in Standard Format
Notes: Contains the result value for all findings copied or derived from MBORRES, in a standard format or standard units. MBSTRESC should store all results or findings in character format; if results are numeric, they should also be stored in numeric format in MBSTRESN. For example, if a test has results "+3 MODERATE", "MOD", and "MODERATE" in MBORRES and these results effectively have the same meaning, they could be represented in standard format in MBSTRESC as "MODERATE".

Label: Numeric Result/Finding in Standard Units
Notes: Used for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format; copied in numeric format from MBSTRESC. MBSTRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.

Label: Standard Units
Notes: Standardized units used for MBSTRESC and MBSTRESN.

Label: Result Category
Notes: Used to categorize the result of a finding in a standard format.

Label: Completion Status
Notes: Used to indicate that a question was not asked or a test was not done, or that a test was attempted but did not generate a result. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".

Label: Reason Not Done
Notes: Reason not done. Used in conjunction with MBSTAT when value is NOT DONE. Examples: "BROKEN EQUIPMENT", "SUBJECT REFUSED".

Label: Laboratory/Vendor Name
Notes: Name or identifier of the vendor (e.g., laboratory) that provided the test results.

Label: LOINC Code
Notes: Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes (LOINC) code for the topic variable (e.g., lab test).

Label: Specimen Material Type
Notes: Defines the type of specimen used for a measurement. Examples: "SPUTUM", "BLOOD", "PUS".

Label: Specimen Condition
Notes: Free or standardized text describing the condition of the specimen. Example: "CONTAMINATED".

Label: Specimen Collection Location
Notes: Anatomical location relevant to the collection of the measurement.

Label: Laterality
Notes: Qualifier for specimen collection location further detailing laterality. Examples: "RIGHT", "LEFT", "BILATERAL".

Label: Directionality
Notes: Qualifier for specimen collection location further detailing directionality. Examples: "ANTERIOR", "LOWER", "PROXIMAL".

Label: Method of Test or Examination
Notes: Method of the test or examination. Examples: "GRAM STAIN", "MICROBIAL CULTURE, LIQUID", "QUANTITATIVE REVERSE TRANSCRIPTASE POLYMERASE CHAIN REACTION".

Label: Last Observation Before Exposure Flag
Notes: Operationally derived indicator used to identify the last non-missing value prior to RFXSTDTC. The value should be "Y" or null.

Label: Baseline Flag
Notes: Indicator used to identify a baseline value. Should be "Y" or null. Note that MBBLFL is retained for backward compatibility. The authoritative baseline for statistical analysis is in an ADaM dataset.

Label: Fasting Status
Notes: Indicator used to identify fasting status. Valid values include "Y", "N", "U", or null if not relevant.

Label: Derived Flag
Notes: Used to indicate a derived record (e.g., a record that represents the average of other records such as a computed baseline). Should be "Y" or null.

Label: Visit Number
Notes: Clinical encounter number. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.

Label: Visit Name
Notes: Protocol-defined description of a clinical encounter.

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit
Notes: Planned study day of VISIT. Should be an integer.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the arm for the element which the specimen collection occurred.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the date/time at which the specimen was collected.

Label: Date/Time of Collection
Notes: Date/time of specimen collection.

Label: Study Day of Visit/Collection/Exam
Notes: Study day of the specimen collection, measured as integer days. Algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in Demographics. This formula should be consistent across the submission.

Label: Planned Time Point Name
Notes: Text description of time when specimen should be taken. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See MBTPTNUM and MBTPTREF. Examples: "Start", "5 min post".

Label: Planned Time Point Number
Notes: Numeric version of MBTPT used in sorting.

Label: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref
Notes: Planned elapsed time (in ISO 8601) relative to a planned fixed reference (MBTPTREF). This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date time variable. Represented as an ISO 8601 duration. Examples: "-PT15M" to represent the period of 15 minutes prior to the reference point indicated by MBTPTREF, or "PT8H" to represent the period of 8 hours after the reference point indicated by MBTPTREF.

Label: Time Point Reference
Notes: Name of the fixed reference point referred to by MBELTM, MBTPTNUM, and MBTPT. Example: "PREVIOUS DOSE".

Label: Date/Time of Reference Time Point
Notes: Date/time for a fixed reference time point, MBTPTREF.

FASTRESC should store all results or findings in character format; if results are numeric, they should also be stored in numeric format in FASTRESN. For example, if a test has results "NONE", "NEG", and "NEGATIVE" in FAORRES, and these results effectively have the same meaning; they could be represented in standard format in FASTRESC as "NEGATIVE".

Label: Numeric Result/Finding in Standard Units
Notes: Used for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format; copied in numeric format from FASTRESC. FASTRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.

Label: Standard Units
Notes: Standardized unit used for FASTRESC and FASTRESN.

Label: Completion Status
Notes: Used to indicate that the measurement was not done. Should be null if a result exists in FAORRES.

Label: Reason Not Performed
Notes: Describes why a question was not answered. Example: "Subject refused". Used in conjunction with FASTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Label: Location of the Finding About
Notes: Used to specify the location of the clinical evaluation. Example: "ARM".

Label: Laterality
Notes: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing laterality. Examples: "RIGHT", "LEFT", "BILATERAL".

Label: Last Observation Before Exposure Flag
Notes: Operationally-derived indicator used to identify the last non-missing value prior to RFXSTDTC. The value should be "Y" or null.

Label: Baseline Flag
Notes: Indicator used to identify a baseline value. The value should be "Y" or null. Note that FABLFL is retained for backward compatibility. The authoritative baseline flag for statistical analysis is in an ADaM dataset.

Label: Evaluator
Notes: Role of the person who provided the evaluation. Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). Should be null for records that contain collected or derived data. Examples: "INVESTIGATOR", "ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE", "VENDOR".

Label: Visit Number
Notes: 1. Clinical encounter number. \n 2. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.

Label: Visit Name

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit
Notes: Planned study day of the visit based upon RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm

Label: Epoch

Label: Date/Time of Collection
Notes: Collection date and time of findings assessment represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Study Day of Collection
Notes: 1. Study day of collection, measured as integer days. \n 2. Algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in Demographics. This formula should be consistent across the submission.

Label: Group ID
Notes: Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Label: Reference ID
Notes: Internal or external specimen identifier. Example: "Specimen ID".

Label: Sponsor-Defined Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined identifier.

Label: Skin Response Test or Exam Short Name

Label: Skin Response Test or Examination Name
Notes: Verbatim name of the test or examination used to obtain the measurement or finding. The value in SRTEST cannot be longer than 40 characters. Example: "Wheal Diameter".

Label: Object of the Observation
Notes: Used to describe the object or focal point of the findings observation that is represented by --TEST. Examples: the dose of the immunogenic material or the allergen associated with the response (e.g., "Johnson Grass IgE 0.15 BAU mL").

Label: Category for Test
Notes: Used to define a category of topic-variable values across subjects.

Label: Subcategory for Test
Notes: A further categorization of SRCAT values.

Label: Results or Findings in Original Units
Notes: Results of measurement or finding as originally received or collected.

Label: Original Units
Notes: Original units in which the data were collected. The unit for SRORRES. Example: "mm".

Label: Character Result/Finding in Std Format
Notes: Contains the result value for all findings copied or derived from SRORRES, in a standard format or in standard units. SRSTRESC should store all results or findings in character format; if results are numeric, they should also be stored in numeric format in SRSTRESN.

Label: Numeric Results/Findings in Std. Units
Notes: Used for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format; copied in numeric format from SRSTRESC. SRSTRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.

Label: Standard Units
Notes: Standardized units used for SRSTRESC and SRSTRESN. Example: "mm".

Label: Completion Status
Notes: Used to indicate exam not done. Should be null if a result exists in SRORRES.

Label: Reason Not Done
Notes: Describes why a measurement or test was not performed. Used in conjunction with SRSTAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Label: Vendor Name
Notes: Name or identifier of the laboratory or vendor who provided the test results.

Label: Specimen Type
Notes: Defines the types of specimen used for a measurement. Example: "SKIN".

Label: Location Used for Measurement

Label: Laterality

Label: Method of Test or Examination
Notes: Method of test or examination. Examples: "ELISA", "EIA", "MICRONEUTRALIZATION ASSAY", "PLAQUE REDUCTION NEUTRALIZATION ASSAY".

Label: Last Observation Before Exposure Flag

Label: Baseline Flag

Label: Evaluator

Label: Visit Number

Label: Visit Name

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit
Notes: Planned study day of the visit based upon RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm

Label: Epoch

Label: Date/Time of Collection
Notes: Collection date and time of an observation represented in ISO 8601.

Label: Study Day of Visit/Collection/Exam
Notes: Actual study day of visit/collection/exam expressed in integer days relative to sponsor- defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Planned Time Point Name
Notes: Text description of time when measurement should be taken. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See SRTPTNUM and SRTPTREF. Examples: "START", "5 MIN POST".

Label: Planned Time Point Number
Notes: Numerical version of SRTPT to aid in sorting.

Label: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref
Notes: Planned elapsed time (in ISO 8601) relative to a fixed time point reference (SRTPTREF). Not a clock time or a date time variable. Represented as an ISO 8601 duration. Examples: "-PT15M" to represent the period of 15 minutes prior to the reference point indicated by EGTPTREF, "PT8H" to represent the period of 8 hours after the reference point indicated by SRTPTREF.

Label: Time Point Reference
Notes: Name of the fixed reference point referred to by SRELTM, SRTPTNUM, and SRTPT. Example: "INTRADERMAL INJECTION".

Label: Date/Time of Reference Time Point
Notes: Date/time of the reference time point, SRTPTREF.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Related Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s). Null for comments collected on a general comments or additional information CRF page.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.

Label: Identifying Variable
Notes: Identifying variable in the parent dataset that identifies the record(s) to which the comment applies. Examples AESEQ or CMGRPID. Used only when individual comments are related to domain records. Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.

Label: Identifying Variable Value
Notes: Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s). Used only when individual comments are related to domain records. Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.

Label: Comment Reference
Notes: Sponsor-defined reference associated with the comment. May be the CRF page number (e.g., 650), or a module name (e.g., DEMOG), or a combination of information that identifies the reference (e.g. 650-VITALS-VISIT 2).

Label: Comment
Notes: The text of the comment. Text over 200 characters can be added to additional columns COVAL1-COVALn. See Assumption 3.

Label: Evaluator
Notes: Role of the person who provided the evaluation. Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). Example: "INVESTIGATOR".

Label: Evaluator Identifier
Notes: Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in --EVAL. Examples: "RADIOLOGIST", "RADIOLOGIST 1", "RADIOLOGIST 2".

Label: Date/Time of Comment
Notes: Date/time of comment on dedicated comment form. Should be null if this is a child record of another domain or if comment date was not collected.

Label: Study Day of Comment
Notes: Study day of the comment, in integer days. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product. This must be a unique value, and could be a compound identifier formed by concatenating STUDYID-SITEID-SUBJID.

Label: Subject Identifier for the Study
Notes: Subject identifier, which must be unique within the study. Often the ID of the subject as recorded on a CRF.

Label: Subject Reference Start Date/Time
Notes: Reference start date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 character format. Usually equivalent to date/time when subject was first exposed to study treatment. See assumption 9 for additional detail on when RFSTDTC may be null.

Label: Subject Reference End Date/Time
Notes: Reference end date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 character format. Usually equivalent to the date/time when subject was determined to have ended the trial, and often equivalent to date/time of last exposure to study treatment. Required for all randomized subjects; null for screen failures or unassigned subjects.

Label: Date/Time of First Study Treatment
Notes: First date/time of exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, equal to the earliest value of EXSTDTC.

Label: Date/Time of Last Study Treatment
Notes: Last date/time of exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, equal to the latest value of EXENDTC (or the latest value of EXSTDTC if EXENDTC was not collected or is missing).

Label: Date/Time of First Challenge Agent Admin
Notes: Used only when protocol specifies a challenge agent to induce a condition that the investigational treatment is intended to cure, mitigate, treat, or prevent. Equal to the earliest value of AGSTDTC for the challenge agent.

Label: Date/Time of Last Challenge Agent Admin
Notes: Used only when protocol specifies a challenge agent to induce a condition that the investigational treatment is intended to cure, mitigate, treat, or prevent. Equal to the latest value of AGENDTC for the challenge agent (or the latest value of AGSTDTC if AGENDTC was not collected or is missing).

Label: Date/Time of Informed Consent
Notes: Date/time of informed consent in ISO 8601 character format. This will be the same as the date of informed consent in the Disposition domain, if that protocol milestone is documented. Would be null only in studies not collecting the date of informed consent.

Label: Date/Time of End of Participation
Notes: Date/time when subject ended participation or follow-up in a trial, as defined in the protocol, in ISO 8601 character format. Should correspond to the last known date of contact. Examples include completion date, withdrawal date, last follow-up, date recorded for lost to follow up, and death date.

Label: Date/Time of Death
Notes: Date/time of death for any subject who died, in ISO 8601 format. Should represent the date/time that is captured in the clinical-trial database.

Label: Subject Death Flag
Notes: Indicates the subject died. Should be "Y" or null. Should be populated even when the death date is unknown.

Label: Study Site Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a site within a study.

Label: Investigator Identifier
Notes: An identifier to describe the Investigator for the study. May be used in addition to SITEID. Not needed if SITEID is equivalent to INVID.

Label: Investigator Name
Notes: Name of the investigator for a site.

Label: Date/Time of Birth
Notes: Date/time of birth of the subject.

Label: Age
Notes: Age expressed in AGEU. May be derived from RFSTDTC and BRTHDTC, but BRTHDTC may not be available in all cases (due to subject privacy concerns).

Label: Age Units
Notes: Units associated with AGE.

Label: Sex
Notes: Sex of the subject.

Label: Race
Notes: Race of the subject. Sponsors should refer to the FDA guidance2 regarding the collection of race. See assumption below regarding RACE.

Label: Ethnicity
Notes: The ethnicity of the subject. Sponsors should refer to the FDA guidance1 regarding the collection of ethnicity.

Label: Planned Arm Code
Notes: ARMCD is limited to 20 characters. It is not subject to the character restrictions that apply to TESTCD. The maximum length of ARMCD is longer than for other "short" variables to accommodate the kind of values that are likely to be needed for crossover trials. For example, if ARMCD values for a 7-period crossover were constructed using 2-character abbreviations for each treatment and separating hyphens, the length of ARMCD values would be 20. If the subject was not assigned to a trial arm, ARMCD is null and ARMNRS is populated. \n With the exception of studies which use multistage arm assignments, must be a value of ARMCD in the Trial Arms dataset.

Label: Description of Planned Arm
Notes: Name of the arm to which the subject was assigned. If the subject was not assigned to an arm, ARM is null and ARMNRS is populated. \n With the exception of studies which use multistage arm assignments, must be a value of ARM in the Trial Arms dataset.

Label: Actual Arm Code
Notes: Code of actual arm. ACTARMCD is limited to 20 characters. It is not subject to the character restrictions that apply to TESTCD. The maximum length of ACTARMCD is longer than for other short variables to accommodate the kind of values that are likely to be needed for crossover trials. \n With the exception of studies which use multistage arm assignments, must be a value of ARMCD in the Trial Arms dataset. \n If the subject was not assigned to an arm or followed a course not described by any planned arm, ACTARMCD is null and ARMNRS is populated.

Label: Description of Actual Arm
Notes: Description of actual arm. \n With the exception of studies which use multistage arm assignments, must be a value of ARM in the Trial Arms dataset. \n If the subject was not assigned to an arm or followed a course not described by any planned arm, ACTARM is null and ARMNRS is populated.

Label: Reason Arm and/or Actual Arm is Null
Notes: A coded reason that arm variables (ARM and ARMCD) and/or actual arm variables (ACTARM and ACTARMCD) are null. Examples: "SCREEN FAILURE", "NOT ASSIGNED", "ASSIGNED, NOT TREATED", "UNPLANNED TREATMENT". It is assumed that if the arm and actual arm variables are null, the same reason applies to both arm and actual arm.

Label: Description of Unplanned Actual Arm
Notes: A description of actual treatment for a subject who did not receive treatment described in a planned trial arm.

Label: Country
Notes: Country of the investigational site in which the subject participated in the trial. \n \n Generally represented using ISO 3166-1 Alpha-3. Note that regulatory agency specific requirements (e.g., US FDA) may require other terminologies; in such cases, follow regulatory requirements.

Label: Date/Time of Collection
Notes: Date/time of demographic data collection.

Label: Study Day of Collection
Notes: Study day of collection measured as integer days.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. Should be assigned to be consistent chronological order.

Label: Element Code
Notes: 1. ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. If an encountered element differs from the planned element to the point that it is considered a new element, then use "UNPLAN" as the value for ETCD to represent this element.

Notes: The name of the element. If ETCD has a value of "UNPLAN", then ELEMENT should be null.

Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the element within the subject's assigned trial arm.

Label: Epoch
Notes: Epoch associated with the element in the planned sequence of elements for the arm to which the subject was assigned.

Label: Start Date/Time of Element
Notes: Start date/time for an element for each subject.

Label: End Date/Time of Element
Notes: End date/time for an element for each subject.

Label: Study Day of Start of Element
Notes: Study day of start of element relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Study Day of End of Element
Notes: Study day of end of element relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Description of Unplanned Element
Notes: Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned element. Used only if ETCD has the value of "UNPLAN".

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number to ensure uniqueness of subject records. Should be assigned to be consistent chronological order.

Label: Disease Milestone Instance Name
Notes: Name of the specific disease milestone. For types of disease milestones that can occur multiple times, the name will end with a sequence number. Example: "HYPO1".

Label: Disease Milestone Type
Notes: The type of disease milestone. Example: "HYPOGLYCEMIC EVENT".

Label: Start Date/Time of Milestone
Notes: Start date/time of milestone instance (if milestone is an intervention or event) or date of milestone (if Milestone is a finding).

Label: End Date/Time of Milestone
Notes: End date/time of disease milestone instance.

Label: Study Day of Start of Milestone
Notes: Study day of start of disease milestone instance, relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Label: Study Day of End of Milestone
Notes: Study day of end of disease milestone instance, relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Notes: Unique identifier for a study.
