Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Visit Number

Label: Visit Name
Notes: Protocol-defined description of a clinical encounter.

Label: Pre-specified
Notes: Used to indicate whether the visit was planned (i.e., visits specified in the TV domain). Value is "Y" for planned visits, null for unplanned visits.

Label: Occurrence
Notes: Used to record whether a planned visit occurred. The value is null for unplanned visits.

Label: Reason for Occur Value
Notes: The reason for the value in SVOCCUR. If SVOCCUR="N", SVREASOC is the reason the visit did not occur.

Label: Contact Mode
Notes: The way in which the visit was conducted. Examples: "IN PERSON", "TELEPHONE CALL", "IVRS".

Label: Epi/Pandemic Related Change Indicator
Notes: Indicates whether the visit was changed due to an epidemic or pandemic.

Label: Planned Study Day of Visit

Notes: End date/time of the observation represented in IS0 8601 character format.

Notes: Actual study day of end of observation expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Label: Transition Rule
Notes: If the trial design allows a subject to transition to an element other than the next element in sequence, then the conditions for transitioning to those other elements, and the alternative element sequences, are specified in this rule (e.g., "Responders go to washout").

Label: Anchor Variable Name

Label: Offset from the Anchor

Label: Planned Assessment Interval

Notes: The lower limit of the allowed range for the planned interval between disease assessments represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Planned Assessment Interval Maximum
Notes: The upper limit of the allowed range for the planned interval between disease assessments represented in ISO 8601 character format.

Label: Maximum Number of Actual Assessments
Notes: This variable must represent the maximum number of actual assessments for the analysis that this disease assessment schedule describes. Label: Rule for Start of Element
Notes: Describes condition for beginning element.

Label: Rule for End of Element

Label: Planned Duration of Element
Notes: Planned duration of element in ISO 8601 format. Used when the rule for ending the element is applied after a fixed duration.

Label: Study Identifier

Label: Incl/Excl Criterion Short Name
Notes: Short name IETEST. It can be used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical to a horizontal format. Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Criterion
Notes: Full text of the inclusion or exclusion criterion. The prefix "IE" is used to ensure consistency with the IE domain.

Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Category
Notes: Used for categorization of the inclusion or exclusion criteria.

Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Subcategory
Notes: A further categorization of the exception criterion. Can be used to distinguish criteria for a sub-study or to categorize as major or minor exceptions. Examples: "MAJOR", "MINOR".

Label: Inclusion/Exclusion Criterion Rule

Label: Protocol Criteria Versions

Label: Disease Milestone Type

Label: Disease Milestone Definition

Label: Disease Milestone Repetition Indicator
Notes: Indicates whether this is a disease milestone that can occur only once ("N") or a type of disease milestone that can occur multiple times ("Y").

Label: Group ID
Notes: Used to tie together a group of related records.

Label: Trial Summary Parameter Short Name
Notes: TSPARMCD (the companion to TSPARM) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that TSPARMCD will need to serve as variable names. Examples: "AGEMIN", "AGEMAX".

Label: Trial Summary Parameter

Label: Parameter Value

Label: Parameter Value Null Flavor
Notes: Null flavor for the value of TSPARM, to be populated only if TSVAL is null.

Label: Parameter Value Code
Notes: This is the code of the term in TSVAL. For example, "6CW7F3G59X" is the code for gabapentin; "C49488" is the code for Y. The length of this variable can be longer than 8 to accommodate the length of the external terminology.

Label: Name of the Reference Terminology
Notes: The name of the reference terminology from which TSVALCD is taken. For example; CDISC CT, SNOMED, ISO 8601.

Label: Version of the Reference Terminology
Notes: The version number of the reference terminology, if applicable.

Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Description of Planned Arm
Notes: 1. Name given to an arm or treatment group. \n 2. If the timing of visits for a trial does not depend on which arm a subject is in, then Arm should be left blank.

Label: Visit Start Rule
Notes: Rule describing when the visit starts, in relation to the sequence of elements.

Label: Visit End Rule
Notes: Rule describing when the visit ends, in relation to the sequence of elements.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Non-host Organism Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined identifier for a non-host organism. NHOID should be populated with an intuitive name based on the identity of the organism as reported by the lab. It must be unique for each unique organism as defined by the specific values of the organism's entire known taxonomy described by pairs of OIPARMCD and OIVAL .

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number to given to ensure uniqueness within a parameter within an organism (NHOID) within dataset.

Label: Non-host Organism ID Element Short Name
Notes: Short name of the taxon being described. Examples: "GROUP", "GENTYP", "SUBTYP".

Label: Non-host Organism ID Element Name
Notes: Name of the taxon being described. Examples: "Group", "Genotype", "Subtype".

Label: Non-host Organism ID Element Value
Notes: Value for the taxon in OIPARMCD/OIPARM for the organism identified by NHOID.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Related Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s).

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Identifying Variable
Notes: Name of the identifying variable in the general-observation-class dataset that identifies the related record(s). Examples: --SEQ, --GRPID.

Label: Identifying Variable Value
Notes: Value of identifying variable described in IDVAR. If --SEQ is the variable being used to describe this record, then the value of --SEQ would be entered here.

Label: Relationship Type
Notes: Identifies the hierarchical level of the records in the relationship. Values should be either "ONE" or "MANY". Used only when identifying a relationship between datasets (as described in Section 8.3, Relating Datasets).

Label: Relationship Identifier
Notes: Unique value within USUBJID that identifies the relationship. All records for the same USUBJID that have the same RELID are considered related/associated. RELID can be any value the sponsor chooses, and is only meaningful within the RELREC dataset to identify the related/associated domain records.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Specimen ID
Notes: Specimen identifier, unique within USUBJID.

Label: Specimen Type
Notes: Defines the type of specimen used for a measurement. Examples: "SERUM", "PLASMA", "URINE", "SOFT TISSUE".

Label: Specimen Parent
Notes: Identifies the REFID of the parent of a specimen to support tracking its genealogy.

Label: Specimen Level
Notes: Identifies the generation number of the sample where the collected sample is considered the first generation.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Label: Pool Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to identify a pool of subjects. If POOLID is entered, POOLDEF records must exist for each subject in the pool and USUBJID must be null. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Label: Related Subject or Pool Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to identify a related subject or pool of subjects. RSUBJID will be populated with either the USUBJID of the related subject or the POOLID of the related pool.

Label: Subject Relationship
Notes: Describes the relationship of the subject identified in USUBJID or the pool identified in POOLID to the subject or pool identified in RSUBJID.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Study identifier of the parent record(s).

Label: Related Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s).

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product. This is the value of USUBJID in the parent record(s).

Label: Identifying Variable
Notes: Identifying variable in the dataset that identifies the related record(s). Examples: --SEQ, --GRPID.

Label: Identifying Variable Value
Notes: Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s).

Label: Qualifier Variable Name
Notes: The short name of the qualifier variable, which is used as a column name in a domain view with data from the parent domain. The value in QNAM cannot be longer than 8 characters, nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST" is not valid). QNAM cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. This will often be the column name in the sponsor's operational dataset.

Label: Qualifier Variable Label
Notes: This is the long name or label associated with QNAM. The value in QLABEL cannot be longer than 40 characters. This will often be the column label in the sponsor's original dataset.

Label: Data Value
Notes: Result of, response to, or value associated with QNAM. A value for this column is required; no records can be in SUPP-- with a null value for QVAL.

Label: Origin
Notes: Because QVAL can represent a mixture of collected (on a CRF), derived, or assigned items, QORIG is used to indicate the origin of this data. Examples: "CRF", "Assigned", "Derived". See Section 4.1.8, Origin Metadata.

Label: Evaluator
Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). Should be null for records that contain objectively collected or derived data. Examples: "ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE", "STATISTICIAN", "DATABASE ADMINISTRATOR", "CLINICAL COORDINATOR".
